contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox French commune |name = Montreuil |image coat of arms = Blason ville fr Montreuil-sur-Mer (Pas-de-Calais).svg |region = [[Nord-Pas de Calais]] |department = [[Pas-de-Calais]] |arrondissement = Montreuil |canton = Montreuil |INSEE = 62588 |postal code = 62170 |mayor = Bruno Béthouart |term = |intercommunality = [[Communauté de communes du Montreuillois]] |longitude = 1.763 |latitude = 50.4648 |elevation m = |elevation min m = 2 |elevation max m = 43 |area km2 = 2.85 |population = 2498 |population date = 2006 }} '''Montreuil''' or '''Montreuil-sur-Mer''' ({{IPA-fr|mɔ̃tʁœj syʁ mɛʁ}}) is a [[Subprefectures in France|sub-prefecture]] in the [[Pas-de-Calais]] [[Departments of France|department]] in northern [[France]]. It is located on the [[Canche]] river, not far from [[Étaples]]. The sea, however, is now some distance away. ==Sights== It is surrounded by medieval ramparts, part of the reinforcement work of the famed French military engineer [[Vauban]] from his fortification of northern France in the 17th century. ==Demographics== Population (1999): 2,688 inhabitants for the city, 21,603 inhabitants for the canton and 99,288 inhabitants for the arrondissement. ==History== Montreuil was the headquarters of the [[British Army]] in France during the [[First World War]]. [[Douglas Haig, 1st Earl Haig|General Haig]] was quartered in the nearby [[Château de Beaurepaire]]. A statue commemorating his stay can be seen outside the theatre on the Place Charles de Gaulle. During the German occupation of the town during the Second World War, the statue was taken down. It was never found and is thought to have been melted down. It was rebuilt in the 1950s, using the sculptor's original mould. ==Literature== [[Lawrence Sterne]] visited the town in 1765. He recounted his visit through the eyes of the narrator of his novel ''[[A Sentimental Journey Through France and Italy]]'' (1768). Montreuil is the setting for part of [[Victor Hugo]]'s novel ''[[Les Misérables]]'', where it is identified only as M____-sur-M__ in past translations. Hugo had spent several vacations in Montreuil.<ref>Edward Behr, ''The Complete Book of Les Misérables'' (Arcade, 1993), 29</ref> ==International relations== {{See also|List of twin towns and sister cities in France}} ===Twin towns — Sister cities=== Montreuil is [[town twinning|twinned]] with: * {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Slough]], [[United Kingdom]] ==Gallery== <gallery> File:Montreuil Saint-saulve portail.jpg|Church, Montreuil image:Walls of Montreuil-sur-Mer, France.JPG|Walls of Montreuil File:Rempart_de_la_ville_de_Montreuil-sur-Mer.JPG|Ramparts File:Chapelle Sainte-Austreberthe Montreuil-sur-Mer2.jpg|Chapelle Sainte-Austreberthe File:Street in Montreuil-sur-Mer, France.JPG|A street in Montreuil-sur-Mer File:Église abbatiale Saint-Saulve Montreuil-sur-Mer.jpg|Église abbatiale Saint-Saulve </gallery> ==See also== *[[Communes of the Pas-de-Calais department]] ==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.insee.fr/fr/methodes/nomenclatures/cog/fichecommunale.asp?codedep=62&codecom=588 INSEE commune file] ; ==External links== * [http://montreuil62.free.fr/ Montreuil-sur-Mer official website] (in French) * [http://www.remembrancetrails-northernfrance.com/visit-the-sites/the-allies-logisitics-base-on-the-channel-coast/equestrian-statue-of-field-marshal-haig-montreuil-sur-mer.html The equestrian statue of Field Marshal Haig on the website "Remembrance Trails of the Great War in Northern France"] {{Commons|Montreuil-sur-Mer|Montreuil-sur-Mer}} {{Pas-de-Calais communes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Montreuil, Pas-De-Calais}} [[Category:Communes of Pas-de-Calais]] [[Category:Subprefectures in France]] {{PasdeCalais-geo-stub}}
